_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This document contains an executive summary of the policies, procedures, and activities for compliance with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's (USEPA's) Accidental Release Prevention Requirements - Risk Management Program pursuant to Title 40 Part 68 of the Code of Federal Regulations (40 CFR 68) for the Dominion Energy Questar Pipeline (DEQP) Kastler Dew Point Plant (DPP).



The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source [40 CFR 68.155(a)]:



DEQP is committed to employee, public, and environmental safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by the release prevention program that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the processes at the facility.  It is DEQP's policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances.  If a release does occur, operations personnel are at hand to control and mitigate the effects of the release, as applicable within their level of training and ability; however, the facility is classified as non-responding.  DEQP has contracted Clean Harbors as an Oil/Spill Response Organization to provide additional emergency response expertise as needed.  Also, as a non-responding facility, DEQP will contact the Uintah County Dispatch (covers Daggett County) to obtain additional resources from Uintah and Daggett Counties including local volunteer fire departments, law enforcement, and emergency medical services depending on the seriousness of an incident.



The stationary source and regulated substances handled [40 CFR 68.155(b)]:



Stationary Source, Regulated Substances Handled, and Covered Process:



Kastler DPP is a natural gas extraction plant that receives natural gas and processes it to remove heavier hydrocarbons from the gas. The inlet gas is chilled in a refrigeration process train to lower the cricondentherm dew point. The chiller system uses propane as a refrigerant in a

closed loop system where the propane is recycled within the system.  By chilling the process gas, natural gas liquids (NGL) condense and are collected in a separator vessel. The residue gas (primarily methane) is compressed and sent back to DEQP's transmission pipeline system for delivery to downstream customers.  The mixed natural gas liquid (NGL) product containing pentane, isopentane [butane, 2-methyl], butane, isobutane [propane, 2-methyl], propane, and ethane is sent to one of the two 45,000-gallon product storage tanks.  The tanks are administratively controlled to 80% of capacity or a maximum of 36,000-gallons each (72,000 gallons in total).  The NGL product is a flammable mixture that meets the NFPA-4 criteria and is present onsite in a process, in an amount, that exceeds the threshold quantity (10,000 pounds) for applicability under the USEPA's Risk Management Program (RMP) requirements.  Also, the propane refrigerant is stored in four 1000-gallon pressurized tanks that collectively exceed the 10,000-pound threshold quantity for a flammable substance, and therefore, are subject to RMP.  No regulated toxic substances above the threshold quantity are present at the facility.



The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps [40 CFR 68.155(c)]:



DEQP has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set out under 40 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Part 68.  Kastler DPP is also subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard under 29 CFR 1910.119 and is classified as a Program 3 process under USEPA's RMP.  The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that are in place at the facility.  These elements of the RMP program are documented in DEQP Standard Practice 4-00-02 (General PSM-RMP procedures) and Standard Practice 4-34-05a (Kastler specific RMP).



Process Safety In

formation - DEQP personnel maintain a detailed record of process safety information that describes the hazards of regulated substances, operating parameters, and equipment designs associated with the regulated process.  Much of this information was compiled during preparation of the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA).  Chemical specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in Safety Data Sheets (SDSs).  The OSHA Hazard Communication Standard (HCS) requires chemical manufacturers, distributors, or importers to provide SDSs to communicate the hazards of hazardous chemical products.



Process Hazard Analysis - DEQP personnel conduct comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with the regulated process are identified and controlled efficiently.  DEQP primarily uses the HAZOP method analysis, supplemented by Checklist techniques, to perform these hazard evaluations.  The studies are undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations and are revalidated at regular intervals of 5 years.  Any findings related to the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner.

 

Operating Procedures - For the purposes of safely conducting activities within the covered process, DEQP maintains written operating procedures in Standard Practice 4-34-05 that provide clear instructions for safely conducting activities involved in each covered process consistent with process safety.  These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown, and startup after a turnaround.  The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the processes.  Safe work practices have been developed to provide for the control of hazards during operations such as lockout/tagout; confined space entry; opening process equipment or pipi

ng; and control over entrance into a stationary source by maintenance, contractor, laboratory, or other support personnel. These safe work practices apply to employees and contractor employees.



Training - DEQP has a training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating processes are competent in the operating procedures associated with these processes.  Initial employee training is provided, and refresher training is conducted at least every three years or more frequently as needed.  Employee training is documented, and a record of training is maintained onsite for at least three years.



Mechanical Integrity - Written procedures in Standard Practice 4-34-05 are in place for maintaining the on-going integrity of process equipment, which incorporate training for process maintenance activities, inspection and testing, corrective action for equipment deficiencies, and the application of quality assurance measures. Documented maintenance checks are carried out on process equipment to ensure proper operation and maintenance.  Process equipment examined by these checks includes among others; pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, and controls and pumps.  Qualified and trained personnel carry out maintenance operations at the site.  Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.  Kastler DPP also incorporates quality assurance measures to ensure that equipment and parts are suitable for the process application for which they will be used.



Management of Change - Written procedures are in place to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment, and procedures.  These procedures are updated as needed.  Process operators, maintenance personnel, or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of any process changes and are offered training to understand modi

fications.



Pre-startup Safety Reviews - Pre-startup safety reviews related to new processes and modifications in established processes are conducted as a regular practice at Kastler DPP.  These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction and installed equipment meet design specifications, and that safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.



Compliance Audits - Regularly scheduled audits are conducted to determine whether the provisions set out under the RMP rule are being properly implemented.  The audits are conducted by at least one person knowledgeable in the process and are conducted at least every three years.  Audit findings are documented in a report and corrective actions are undertaken in a safe and prompt manner.  Kastler DPP maintains a record of the two most recent compliance audit reports, as applicable. 



Incident Investigation - Any incident that results in or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance is promptly investigated.  An incident investigation is initiated as promptly as possible, but no later than 48 hours after the incident, and will involve at least one person knowledgeable in the process involved. 

An investigation is undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent a release from reoccurring.  A report is prepared at the conclusion of the investigation and includes any resolutions and/or corrective actions.  All incident reports are retained for a minimum of five years.



Employee Participation - DEQP believes that PSM and accident prevention is a team effort.  Employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and recommend improvements.  In addition, employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP rule, including information resulting from process ha

zard analyses.



Hot Work Permit - Kastler DPP personnel will issue a hot work permit for hot work operations conducted on or near a covered process.  The permit shall document that the fire prevention and protection requirements have been implemented prior to beginning the hot work operations; it shall indicate the date(s) authorized for hot work; and identify the object on which hot work is to be performed. The permit will be kept on file until completion of the hot work operations.  DEQP hot work procedures are governed by Standard Practice 8-20-03.



Contractors - DEQP hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities.  Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of safety performance of the contractor is carried out and before any contractors perform work at Kastler DPP, they undergo an orientation.  During this orientation contractors are made aware of the known potential hazards related to the work, the hazards of regulated substances, and the safe work procedures insisted on by DEQP.  In addition, they are familiarized with the Hot Work Permit Policy and the Lock Out/Tag Out Procedures.  Contractors are further informed of all the procedures for emergency response, should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur.  Emergency response information includes evacuation routes and personnel assembly points.  DEQP documents that all contract personnel have received the training and understand its importance and purpose.



Chemical Specific Prevention Steps - The covered processes at Kastler DPP present hazards that must be managed to ensure continued safe operation.  Collectively, the prevention program activities described above help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and human error.  In addition, Kastler DPP incorporates safety features on its equipment to help (a) quickly detect a release (e.g., hydrocarbon detectors with alarms; (b) contain/control a release (

e.g., safety valves, diking, and enclosures), and (c) reduce the consequences of (mitigate) a release (e.g., employee training on extinguishing small fires).



The five-year accident history [40 CFR 68.155(d)]:



Kastler DPP has had zero RMP reportable incidents in the previous five years.



The emergency response program [40 CFR 68.155(e)]:



DEQP maintains a SharePoint website for company Standard Practices that include emergency response information for individual sites.  This website is readily available for use on employee computer terminals and the emergency response plan is also kept onsite for immediate access should an emergency response be required.  The Kastler DPP Operations & Maintenance Standard Practice 4-34-05 contains an emergency response plan that addresses accidental releases of regulated substances and is in place to protect worker and public safety, as well as the environment.



The plan includes actions to be taken including adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, and notifications to local emergency response agencies and the public.  To ensure proper function, emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced.  In addition, the plan is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place within the processes that would require a modified emergency response.  In the event of an emergency, DEQP will immediately notify 911 (Uintah County Dispatch).  The professional and volunteer emergency responders will coordinate emergency response activities.



The emergency plan has been coordinated with the Daggett County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).



Planned changes to improve safety [40 CFR 68.155(f)]:



DEQP is committed to continuous improvement and looks for opportunities to improve safety systems and programs at the facility by reinforcing the importance of safety on a daily basis, encouraging employee participation, giving all employees and contractors stop work authority, and implementi
ng best practices as they evolve and become known.
